titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. I employed three hours this morning in writing— Walk before Breakfast and again before dinner— The Season is manifesting itself in all its severity.— I had a morning visit from Count de Bruges, and Mr Bayard spent part of the Evening with us; untill 11. He proposed a meeting on Monday at 2 O’Clock to consult together on the propriety of fixing a time beyond which he should not wait here, for the official information from this Government that the British Ministers have rejected the Emperors offered Mediation— I agreed to the meeting. Received from Count Romanzoff the Passport for Mr Todd, and Coll: Milligan, and addressed another Note to him concerning the cases of the Hector, and the Commerce.— I gave the leisure of the day to Biot and La Croix.— Gracious God! grant thy blessing upon my intentions; confirm the stability of my will; with Patience, Perseverance, Fortitude— Enlighen my Understanding, purify my heart, rule and correct my temper, and if it be thy will, let my life be useful upon Earth!

2. VI:30. Wrote to my father— After Breakfast I spent three hours in instructing Charles, which I must now do for the ensuing three weeks, during which there is a Vacation at Mr Fishwick’s school. I read prayers for the second Sunday after Christmas, and Massillon’s paraphrase of the 12th: Psalm, with his Sermon for the day of the Circumcision. 1. January— It is that on the divinity of Jesus Christ—one of the most eloquent and most powerful in reasoning of the Bishop’s discourses.— One of his arguments in which I think there is great weight is drawn from the countenance given by Christ to the idea of his Divinity, and the unfavourable operation upon his character of the supposition that he gave such countenance without foundation— I see that Abbadie has used the same argument in a manner which Jortin censures as indiscreet in his Remarks on ecclesiastical history. But Jortin was himself an Arian or a Socinian, though a clergyman of the Church of England.— I think this apparent from the general tenor of his remarks.— Coll: Milligan and Mr Todd called upon me this morning, and took their Passport— They have postponed their departure untill Wednesday.

3. VI.45. The weather has become so cold that I find it almost impracticable to hold a pen, and by a concurrence of Circumstance which has often happened to me, I have just now occasion to write more than usual— I did write though with pain this morning untill Breakfast time— Gave Charles his lessons of two or three hours— Mr Lewis called on me to mention his having received a letter from Mr Willing at Gothenburg, with news from America, of which it is best to wait for the confirmation— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard came according to appointment at 2 O’Clock— Mr Bayard spoke of his anxiety to go away, and proposed that we should send a Note to Count Romanzoff urging an answer of information what had been the determination of the British Government concerning the Emperor’s offer of Mediation.— We agreed to send such a Note, which Mr Bayard asked me to draw up— I told him that as its object had particular reference to his own conduct, and his wish to go away, I thought he would best express his own ideas, to which he assented— Mr Gallatin mentioned that he had had a conference with Count Romanzoff, respecting his own departure, in which he had asked him when an answer might be expected from the Emperor.— The Count could not tell; but had observed to him as in Confidence that it was solely and entirely on our account that he had hitherto delayed to resign his office of Chancellor— That he could not transact the Emperor’s business— That the Emperor had forbidden any other person to write to him, choosing to correspond with him himself— He occasionally wrote him short letters which were all kindness and condescension, but answered nothing upon matters of business— It was impossible for him, the Count therefore to do the business of his Office, and his sole motive for continuing in it had been his wish to close the affair of our Mission.— In the course of our Conversation I found that the project of Mr: Gallatin and Mr Bayard now is to go to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, and apply to Count Nesselrode for the answer which does not come through the channel of Count Romanzoff— The first intimation of this intent was given me by Mr Harris last week, but it was then confined to Mr Gallatin.— It was this day repeatedly suggested by both of them apparently with a view to elicit my opinion of its propriety— But as I made no remark upon it, Mr Bayard at last asked me, whether we ought not to ask Count Romanzoff whether it would not be proper— I then said that as I did not myself think it proper, I could not think it expedient to ask Count Romanzoff’s opinion of its propriety— Both the Gentlemen appeared to be very
strongly affected by this expression of my opinion— They both started instantly from their seats, and walked to and fro in the chamber in directions crossing each other and in great apparent agitation— I observed that there was no proper channel of Communication for them with the Emperor at Head-Quarters— Mr Bayard said there was Nesselrode— I said he was not Minister of foreign Affairs, and would certainly receive no Communication from them without an express order from the Emperor. Mr Gallatin said it was not his idea to go themselves to the Head-Quarters; but to go near enough to them, to send Mr Harris to them; if Harris would go— Mr Bayard said that Harris was willing to go, which Mr Gallatin confirmed, and of which I have no doubt— I said that as it was a matter relating to their personal conduct, they must judge for themselves, and were not at-all bound by my opinion— Gallatin said we might be blamed for not having already sent a Courier of our own to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters after the delay that had occured in the former instance— Bayard said that he was under a great responsibility, if he stayed—and there was also great responsibility in going away.— But the Head-Quarters project is Gallatin’s, who acts without any responsibility at-all.— Bayard has repeatedly expressed his astonishment to me that Gallatin should presume to act at-all, knowing the rejection of his nomination by the Senate; and told me the other day, at Count Romanzoff’s table that if he had received such information, he would not have stayed here two days after receiving it. Bayard said he had thought upon fixing on the 21st: for his departure, as it would be that day six Months since they arrived. He told me on Saturday that Gallatin had said he should go between next Monday and Wednesday— We finally rested upon sending a Note to Count Romanzoff, which Mr Bayard is to draft— This Evening it became again severely cold

4. VI:15.— My Thermometer in the Northern exposition was this morning at -24. The Southern one -22. The Academy’s Register is marked at -30. the cold so severe that it is with extreme difficulty I hold a pen, and I can write very little— Charles’s lessons which occupy full three hours have also suspended almost entirely my astronomical and mathematical enquiries. The weather is clear, but the brightness of the Moon extinguishes almost all the Stars— I observed however this morning two stars of the first magnitude in the meridian, about 6 and 7 O’Clock— I take them to be Arcturus and Spica— I also noticed three Northern Constellations, to be ascertained when I get a Catalogue of Stars or celestial Charts— I see Venus and Mars in the Meridian successively from 4 to 6 in the afternoon—and observe Jupiter rising about 9 in the Evening, and past the Meridian at 6. in the Morning.— Mr Lewis dined and spent the Evening with us.— The northern Thermometer this Evening was at -25 1/2 The Southern one at -23.— The Academy’s Register at -31:2. The severest cold I ever experienced at St: Petersburg.

5. IV. The Cold has penetrated so much into my Bed chamber, that it abridges my sleep— My Thermometers this morning were -24 and -22. The Academy Register -30.2. It has effectually suspended my writing as Charles’s lessons have my reading— I had this day a fire made in my chamber a second time, and easily found occupation for the day. Observed the Moon and stars which were visible, but found no new ones.

6. VI. The Russian Christmas— About 9 this morning I received from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin a notification for a Te Deum at 11. at the Kazan Church, for the splendid successes of the allies, the taking of several Cities in Holland, and the Peace with Persia— I attended with Mr Smith at the Hour— The Empress Mother, the Grand-Dukes, and Grand Duchess Ann were there— Of the Corps Diplomatique, only Count Maistre, Messrs: Bayard and Gallatin, and Mr Jouffroy, the Prussian Chargé d’Affairs. Neither the Duke de Serra-Capriola, Lord Walpole, the Chevalier Bardaxi, nor Captain Guedes were present— The Court circle very thin, and the crowd not great. The Cold had abated to about -25. but the Church doors were so continually opening and shutting that we had a constant fan upon us; during the two hours that the Ceremonies lasted, and before they finished I was thoroughly chilled. Instead of a hand-Bill read by the Minister at War, there was a Proclamation of the Emperor’s, dated at Carlsruhe, read by a Chamberlain— Mr Narishkin told me, it was an order for a Te Deum in all the Churches throughout the Empire, to give thanks to God for that whereas one year ago, all Europe was against Russia, now all Europe was united with Russia in support of the good cause. Count Maistre told me that one of the Bishops who usually officiated at these ceremonies, Theophylact, had lately by an Ukaze from the Emperor been ordered away to his diocese; for having translated a work of Ancillon, a protestant clergyman at Berlin, which the Metropolitan had taken offence at, as containing Atheistic, or Pantheistic doctrines, or what they call in Germany transcendental Spinosism— The Metropolitan had first employed Philaretus, to answer the Book which he had done with great acrimony. Theophylact had prepared a reply, which he was refused permission to print, and the whole matter was laid before the Emperor who had
ordered Theophylact to go to his diocese, and in consequence of the censurable doctrines which he had countenanced, he was forbidden to preach any where but in his diocese; which the Count thought a strange decision— The Count said he believed there was no Atheism, but some protestantism in the doctrines; but the Ancillon was determined to justify himself, and would publish an account of all the proceedings— So that the affair which had already made a très grande sensation would finish by making un bruit épouvantable— After returning home I walked an hour to recover the warmth I had lost at the Church. Mr Bayard spent the Evening with us untill 1/2 past eleven; and was very full of Conversation— He spoke particularly much of Mr Gallatin and not in a very friendly style.— He said they had not more communication with each other than there was between him, Bayard, and me— He spoke sarcastically of the representation Gallatin had made to Count Romanzoff, of the motive for the rejection of his nomination by the Senate— As if it was only the President’s extreme anxiety to keep him in the Office of Secretary of the Treasury— I said that might be the idea conveyed by his Note to Count Romanzoff; but that he had only stated the facts as they were, and I thought the representation a very natural and allowable one— Bayard said he had never seen that note, which surprized me. He added that Gallatin had now another project, which was, on his return to America to ascribe the whole failure of the Negotiation, to the rejection of his nomination; and Bayard thought it was a pretension extremely likely, in the temper of parties to take, and generally to prevail.— He mentioned again his own great anxiety to return home; but said he had concluded to be governed by the opinion of the Majority—either to stay—to go to Head-Quarters or to go home— He had drafted a Note to Count Romanzoff, and given it to Mr Gallatin they day they were here, and Gallatin had returned it to him, not untill just as he was going out (to Princess Michel Galitzin’s) this Evening.— I observed that as to a Majority, I did not know how he would now find one, as Mr Gallatin had declared he considered himself as no longer belonging to the mission; and had very plainly told us that he was aware he was acting without any sort of responsibility, which he very certainly was, being neither accountable to the Executive, nor impeachable by the House of Representatives.— Mr Bayard concurred explicitly in this opinion; and he repeated what he has said to me many times before— That he had a very short notice of his own appointment— That he had barely time to make his preparations for the Voyage, and to settle his domestic and professional affairs.— That his only motive for accepting the appointment was the belief that it might tend to a conciliation of parties.— But as soon as he got on board ship, and turned his mind to the subject he had not an instant of doubt but that the British Government would reject the Mediation, and he told Mr Gallatin so before they had been three days at Sea. That what the British called their maritime rights were their pretensions, and they would never submit them to the judgment of another Nation, but woud support them with their power.

7. Mr Todd came to inform us that he and Coll: Milligan intend to set out upon their Journey to-morrow morning. He afterwards came and dined with us, but Milligan was engaged to Mr Lewis— He came in the Evening about 10. I did not see him, having already retired.— Charles, besides his usual lesson, was busied the whole day in writing and dispatching notes for his party to-morrow Evening.— I rose this morning at VII.

8. V.15. But the cold is so severe that I cannot write. Captain Bates called upon me this morning and asked me to renew his Passport, which I did— He mentioned his intention to leave this City next week, and to go to Holland. He finds nothing to do here, and hopes the change of affairs in Holland will make an opening for business. I dined with Mr Smith at Mr Meyer’s. Mr Gallatin, Mr Bayard, Mr Krehmer, Mr Lewis, and a nephew of Mr Meyer’s formed the Company. Mr Harris was absent; being engaged at Princess Beloselsky’s, as on her fête day. Milligan and Todd went about 4 O’Clock this Afternoon.— Milligan and Bayard quarreled before the Coll: went away, and Milligan spoke of Bayard last Evening at my house with much bitterness.— Bayard asked to day at table whether they intended to travel day and Night, and whether they would probably write to any-body— Mr Gallatin spoke with great virulence against Bonaparte, and with strong panegyric of air Robert Walpole— His early prejudices against him he said, had occasioned some errors in his life (alluding to his share in the whiskey-Insurrection in Pennsylvania) and on reviewing his own conduct he had looked
more particularly into the history of Sir Robert Walpole, and was convinced he was one of the greatest men, and best Ministers that England had ever produced— After dinner I asked Mr Gallatin to allow me to have copies taken of Mr Baring’s two letters to him on the subject of our Mission, which he very readily promised.— I came home between eight and nine in the Evening, and found Charles and all his little company with him in the midst of their Sports— Mr Pflug was here with his brother, and Mrs Krehmer, with her Son George, and daughter Sophia.— Matilda Betancourt, Mr Fishwick’s son and daughter, three sons of Mr Cayley, Moxon, Priestley and Roebuck were here— He had invited all his schoolmates, but about half of them did not come— They had a supper, and went away much satisfied with their entertainment about Midnight— Mr Lewis came shortly before supper.

9— VII:30. During the two preceding Winters I had no fire made in my bed-chamber; but I did not sleep in it last Winter— I intended to have had no fires in it this winter; but as for several days it has been at a temperature of -3 and -4 degrees of Reaumur and the cold still increasing,—I have suffered cold so much in the Night as to be deprived of sleep— My library too adjoining it has grown so cold that for several days I have scarcely been able to write, and Charles this day complained so much of cold fingers that he was barely able to finish his lesson— I therefore had a fire made in the Bed-chamber; which only raised the Thermometer at Night from -4 to +1.— I read prayers for the first Sunday after the Epiphany, and Massillon’s Sermon for that day— Also his Paraphrase of the 12th. Psalm— But I could not write a line the whole day. Mr Bayard spent the Evening with us, and told me that he should send me to-morrow his draft of a Note to Count Romanzoff— He expressed his determination to go away with Mr Gallatin, at the latest in a week or ten days from this time— Mr Smith dined with Mr: Lewis— The Night was clear and I observed the rising of the Moon and Jupiter, a conjunction of which was marked in the Calendar for to-morrow. The Moon rose about half an hour before the Planet, and nearly in the same Quarter—

10. VI. I saw the Moon and Jupiter again after I rose this morning, and in conjuction; that is within one degree of each other— The face of the sky and the aspect of the Stars has now an interest for me that I never knew before— My chamber was again this morning too cold for writing— Mr Bayard called and left with me a draft of his Note for the Chancellor, which he requested me to take and correct or alter as I should think proper— He left with it a minute by Mr Gallatin suggesting great alterations, omissions and transpositions. He said Mr Gallatin had however told him that he should not sign the note. At my request he left it with me, but wished me to return it in time to have the note sent to-morrow. I devoted the Evening to it—translated into French the part of his original which was left after Mr Gallatin’s retrenchments from it, and drew up an additional paragraph, notifying to the Chancellor, Mr Bayard’s intention shortly to ask for his Passports, which he has so repeatedly stated to me in strong terms, and which if sincere I thought it indispensable to be communicated to the Count—

11. Captain Hewet of the Sea-Lion, one of the American Vessels detained at Cronstadt by the War, called upon me this morning with a Note of Introduction from Mr Harris— He said Mr Harris informed him he was going away, and he should wish in the Consul’s absence to have some person to whose advice he might recur, as circumstances might require; and I informed him that my advice should always be at his service, whenever he should think it might be useful to him.— About two O’Clock in the afternoon I called upon Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard with the draft of the Note for Count Romanzoff, as I had prepared it. They both read it over, and suggested some verbal criticisms, and emendations, Mr Gallatin to the French, and Mr Bayard to the English— I readily assented to all the alterations they proposed— At length Mr Bayard said he did not altogether like the closing sentence of my additional paragraph— It was the one stating his intention to ask for his Passports— He said that it had the appearance of his deserting his duty— No—if there was any duty to do he should certainly not go away and leave it for me to do— His idea was in going away to terminate the Mission. I observed that it was neither in his nor in our joint power to terminate the Mission— That could be done only by the Government which sent us, or the Government to which we were accredited—and as to the desertion of his duty, what was the duty to be performed?—simply to receive from this Government, and transmit to our own an official document the substance of which was already perfectly well known to us all. He had conceived himself competent to go alone to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, and ask there for this very document, without needing my co-operation— He had even conceived himself competent to go to England alone, and there make a Treaty, without
needing any concurrence of mine; if he therefore could perform separately, duties of the mission of that magnitude, I could not conceive that the mere act of receiving and transmitting an official paper, was such as he could not leave to be performed separately by me, without any desertion of his duty— He said that any idea he might have had, of going to England was not in an official character, but it was only to sound the dispositions of the Government there; and as to the project of going to Head-Quarters, that was merely an idea that had occurred to him, but upon which he had formed no determination.— I did not reply to either of these Answers, because after bringing to Mr Bayard’s mind the comparison between his own grounds for being prepared to do so much separately, himself, and yet so averse to leaving so little to be performed separately by me, I thought it unnecessary to push him too hard in argument— In his projects of going to England to make a Treaty, all but the signing, (which he explicitly avowed in one of our former Conferences) and of going to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, the thought had never entered his head, that he would be taking the whole mission upon himself, and dismissing me from my share in it as effectually as if I had never been joined in the Commission— I made no objection against his going to England, because supposing it possible that the door for a Negotiation would thereby be kept open, which might promote the work of Peace, I felt it my duty to sacrifice all personal Considerations, to the furtherance of the great public object. I was nevertheless fully aware that the Negotiation if practicable will be accomplished by Mr Bayard the only commissioned Envoy, and by Mr Gallatin, no longer even in the Commission, to the total exclusion of myself— I did think that Mr Bayard before he came to the determination of going to England ought to have thought of this, to have weighed the consideration, and to have consulted me concerning it.— I believe he never thought of it— Certain it is that he never gave me the remotest hint that he had thought of it.— He has now for some weeks been declaring his intention to go away without wasting any longer for the official Communication from this Government, of the rejection by Great-Britain of the Mediation— He has been asking and urging for my advice to him, and expressing the most extreme anxiety to go.— I had in the paragraph I drew up announced his intention of going, and put it on a footing altogether inoffensive to this Government; saying that he would leave to me the care of receiving and transmitting the paper, when it should suit the convenience of this Government to give it— But the instant the idea was presented to Mr Bayard, of my performing separately the mere act of receiving and enclosing an official paper, without his participation— No—it would be a desertion of his duty—and if there was any duty to be performed he would stay. I thought it therefore proper to bring to his view the parallel of his principles in the two cases, and as a bare glimpse was sufficient to make it glaring, I forbore to press the comparison upon him, leaving it to the operation of his own mind— Mr Gallatin said there was an intrinsic difficulty, in Mr Bayard’s returning to America without having first received the document which we expected from this Government— That it related not merely to himself, but to the public Interest, since the Odium of rejecting the Mediation would in the public opinion be thereby transferred from England to Russia— This therefore had suggested to him the idea, of going not to Head-Quarters, but near enough to send Mr Harris to them; as Mr Harris had offered himself to go.— I then said to Mr Bayard that I had drafted the paragraph only on the supposition that he had determined to go.— If there was any doubt on his mind, concerning that point, my paragraph became useless and improper; and I requested him to strike it out.— He said that he should wish to wait for Count Romanzoff’s answer to the main point, before he notified to him his intention of going away. Perhaps that answer would contain something which might vary that determination— He expressed himself perfectly satisfied that my intentions had been good, and it was agreed the paragraph should be struck out.— The remnant of the Note was dispatched by young Gallatin to Mr Harris to be prepared for our signature to-morrow Morning; and as the Gentlemen were about dressing to go and dine at Princess Beloselsky’s, I took my leave of them and immediately returned home— I rose this morning at VII:30.— The temperature of my Bed-chamber has risen by three days warming to +7 degrees: so that I am again able to write in the adjoining chamber— The external cold has this day much moderated by the thermometer’s, but it has blown a heavy gale of wind with snow falling and drifting, so that it was worse for walking than the extreme Cold— The sky has again veiled itself in Clouds— And my Astronomy and Mathematics sleep, at least during Charles’s vacation.— I wrote this Evening about two hours.

12. IV. And my chamber being warmed, I wrote assiduously untill nine. Captain Bates came and I gave him a letter for Mr Bourne at Amsterdam— He said he should go to-morrow Morning— Mr Harris called with the Note to Count Romanzoff, prepared for signature— He said that Mr Gallatin had asked for his Passports and his Audience of leave of the Empress Mother— He also mentioned his own intention of going away— His visit to me on the 31st: of December, I have since perceived was a sounding— Mr Gallatin’s project was to go round by the Emperor’s Head-Quarters taking Bayard and Harris with him, and make the occasion to have a direct Communication with the Emperor— To effect this it was necessary to have my acquiescence and Harris was sent to me to try the experiment without informing me what the real plan was— Harris told me then that Mr Gallatin had concluded to go; and having received a letter from one of his Relations in Geneva, who was very desirous of seeing him, and had proposed to meet him in Switzerland, he would probably go round by the way of Frankfort, now the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters.— But that it was very strange, Mr Bayard would insist upon staying here, and waiting for a document which perhaps this Government never would communicate, so that Mr Gallatin would have to go away alone. It was the next day after this that Mr Bayard came and proposed a conference to fix upon a time beyond which he should no longer wait, and which he proposed should be the 21st: of this Month; six Months from the day of their arrival— Mr Bayard who had uniformly expressed great anxiety to go, then said, that Mr Gallatin hitherto, had always given it as his opinion that he, Bayard, could not go away without receiving the Emperor’s answer. In the conference, the plan of going to Head-Quarters was very gradually disclosed to me, and it was only the great agitation of both the Gentlemen, when it became necessary to express my opinion of it, which shewed me how thoroughly it had been concerted, before I was even given to understand that it was thought of.— The plan as well as that of going to England, is entirely Mr Gallatin’s, who not with standing the vote of the Senate on his nomination, has no inclination to lose any possible opportunity of being still engaged inofficially, in the Negotiation. But Mr Harris told me on the 31st: of December, that it was Mr Gallatin’s opinion that we must yield to Great-Britain upon the point of impressment; because we should never obtain Peace without it; and because we should be unable to carry on the War, for want both of funds and credit— Mr Bayard has expressed this opinion to me, but Gallatin never did— Every intimation of his opinion upon the subject to me has been directly the reverse. He has indeed said nothing on the point of impressment lately; but since our late accounts from America have informed us of the facility with which the Government obtained the late Loan of 7 Millions of Dollars, Gallatin says that he never supposed we should find any difficulty in raising Money, after once adopting the English manner of making lists, instead of the clumsy one of subscriptions.— But with both the Gentlemen prepared to abandon the point of Impressment, and with the determination of the British Government concerning it, as signified in Mr Baring’s last Letter, I doubt whether they will do much good by going to England, unless our Government has totally changed its principles since they gave our Instructions, and as much prepared as Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard to yield the point of Impressment.— I received this afternoon a notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies for a Court to-morrow— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard spent the Evening with us— Mr Gallatin told us he was to have his Audience of leave of the Empress-Mother to-morrow.

13. VI. The morning of the Russian New-Year is always occupied in receiving the visits of all the Court Servants and Messengers of the Public Offices, who came for their customary presents— At noon I went with Mr Smith to the Palace, and attended at the Empress-Mother’s Court— After which we attended the Circle of the Grand-Dukes, Nicholas and Michael, and finally that of the Grand-Duchess Ann— We kissed the hands of the Empress and Grand-Duchess.— We were also shewn into the Hall, where the table was laid for the Empress’s dinner—a table of about sixty covers, and we were allowed to admire the Russian Costumes of the ornaments on the tables.— The Empress Mother was still in extasies at the state of political affairs and rejoycing at the happy auspices under which the new year is commencing.— As between the Empress’s Court and that of the Grand-Dukes we were kept waiting about an hour we were served with a cold Collation consisting of the leg of a cold roast-fowl, (we were about twenty-five in number) with bread, madeira-wine, and a Cordial, in cups and glasses containing each about a table-spoonful— This Collation was an extraordinary impromptu of the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin— Mr. Gallatin and his son took leave, at the Circles—the Chevalier Bardaxi told me of the accident which had befallen his
Lady, whose clothes caught fire yesterday at one of the stoves, and she was very badly burnt. After the Court I paid visits in person to the Minister of Finance, Gourieff, at Countess Litta’s, Count Romanzoffs and Prince Kurakin’s; also to Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and to Mr Harris— He was driving up to his door just as we stopp’d there. He had been with Mr Bayard to Count Romanzoff’s— The Count was not at Court this day, and is said to be much indisposed at his own house— Mr Harris thinks his principal disease is the falling sickness.— On my return home I found two letters from Mr Beasley.— Mr Harris paid us a visit in the Evening— He says that Count Romanzoff received the Treaty of Peace with Persia, from the Emperor under a blank cover— And that the Count seriously talks of going to America— The sky was clear this Evening, but the illuminations thwarted a little our star-gazing amusements.

14. VI:15. The severity of the cold has in part abated, but a walk is still a painful operation— During the extremity of the Season, I have suspended my walks before Breakfast, but continue to take one from 1/2 past 3 to 5 afternoon— I wrote and read a little this morning, carried Charles through his lesson, and amused the Evening by reading English Newspapers.

15. V.15. Wrote untill breakfast, and from that time, untill the hour for my walk, employed the morning with Charles, who wrote a letter to his brother George. I dictated to him, but he wrote it all himself, and was much amused with the occupation. Mr Bayard spent part of the Evening with us.— He is still anxious to go, and determined not to wait more than ten days longer. He told me that he had sent Mr Harris to Count Romanzoff to ascertain whether he would give a direct Answer to our last Note—that the Count had said it was impossible for him to give any other answer than that he had received and would transmit it to the Emperor. The Count was much distressed, and determined to resign his Office— He had however told Mr Harris that he thought Mr Bayard would be justifiable in going away, and at his request, would furnish him with Passports— Mr Bayard proposed sending a new Note to the Count, stating the Evidence we have, of the rejection of the Mediation by the British Government; as the motive for his departure; and asked me if I should have any objection to joining in such a Note— I told him, not if it could be drawn up in such a form, as to avoid giving offence to his Government, and every thing that might irritate our own Country against Russia— For I could not but feel the neglect of the Emperor in delaying the answer we had been so long expecting, and I thought our Country when acquainted with the facts would feel it still more sensibly— He said he would make a draft of such a Note to-morrow and sent it to me for Consideration. He is so much embittered against the Emperor, that I have some apprehension he will betray his feelings in the Note— He says Lord Walpole told him that after their former Conversation together, he had written to Lord Cathcart asking from him the confirmation of the statements he had made, and also to Lord Castlereagh for Instructions concerning it— That he had received from the Emperor’s Head-Quarters a letter mentioning that the day after it was written, Lord Cathcart was to dispatch a Courier to him with his answer.— He added that Mr Gallatin last Evening paid a visit at Mr Kosodavleff’s, and that he shewed him a patent made out for Mr Fulton’s privilege; which he considered as a proof that the Emperor could find time for attending to objects of minor importance.— But I told him I had made the application for Mr Fulton in August, and had been ever since waiting for an Answer— Mr Bayard left us between 11 and 12. and I passed about an hour afterwards in examining the stars, the Evening being unusually clear.

16. VI:45. The weather has in some degree moderated, and the usual consequence of fog and clouds ensued— There was this morning a conjunction of the Moon and Uranus, and they were in the Meridian just before 8 O’Clock— I saw the Moon, but the clouds and daylight prevented me from discerning the Planet.— I read Prayers for the second Sunday after the Epiphany. And Massillon’s Sermon, upon the Example of the Great— The first of the Petit-Careme—preached on the festival of the Purification of the Virgin, which is kept on the 2d: of February, the fortieth day from Christmas— Charles wrote a letter to his brother John.

17. IV:45. The morning being clear I spent an hour or two in surveying the Stars, and marked the Constellations which I take to be the Lyre, the Swan, the Dragon, Cepheus, Cassiopeia, the belt of Perseus, and the Crown, between Arcturus and Lyra— I could ascertain no others; but saw a bright Star rise at about 6 O’Clock in the ENE—which might be the Eagle— The Moon was in the Meridian at VIII:39. but Clouds had risen and I could not see her— Even at this Season in this Country a person who would make Astronomical Observations must seize every half-hour of clear sky, for it scarcely ever lasts longer, and the brightest Nights are chequered with continual successions of thin vapours which rise and pass away from hour to hour. There is however in proportion to the obliquity of the Sphere, a greater number of the Stars always
above the horizon, and therefore always exposed to observation.— After Breakfast, Charles wrote a letter to his Grandfather— I paid a visit to Mr Lewis and Mr Slade— Employed the Evening in reading the English Newspapers.

18. VI:15. Mr Bayard called upon me this afternoon, with a Note from Count Romanzoff, in answer to that which we sent him last week, and a draft of a reply, in which he asks for his Audiences of leave, and his Passports— He desired me to make a translation of it into French, to be ready to morrow-Morning, as he hoped to have his Audiences of leave next Sunday. His intention is to go next Tuesday; untill which time, Mr Gallatin who is now ready to go, will wait for him— I made the translation this Evening— Mr de Tracy spent the latter part of it with us.— Charles went to his party, at Mr Cayley’s.

19. VI:30. There was this morning a conjunction of the Moon and Mercury— The Moon rose at VI:52, and between seven & eight I walked out to see if I could discover either of them— It was 56 hours before the new Moon— I saw her distinctly, about an hour risen above the horizon, and three quarters of an hour before Sunrise; but there was too much daylight to allow me to perceive the Planet, although the sky was as clear as I ever saw it here, and Jupiter was visible untill within half an hour of Sunrise— The Planets Mercury, Saturn, and Uranus are all now in the vicinity of the Sun, but I see Venus and Mars every clear Evening, and Jupiter both Evening and Morning. I attempted to find the Moon in the Meridian, between 10 and 11 O’Clock but there was nothing to be seen. I called upon Messrs: Bayard and Gallatin between 2 and 3 in the afternoon. In my Translation of the Note to Count Romanzoff I had made but one alteration from the Original; it was in relation to Mr Bayard’s determination to go away— He had mentioned it as a resolution jointly concluded as indispensable, by us both— I expressed it so as to appear his own determination as it really is.— He said that he had intentionally stated it as our joint conclusion, because he had wished it to be the result of my advice as well, as of his own opinion— I observed that by signing the Note I made myself responsible for all the reasoning upon which his resolution to go had been formed, but I thought it best, that the resolution itself should appear as his own— He said if so, it should go as I preferred, and perhaps there might be a point of delicacy in my appearing to advise his going away— Mr Gallatin at my request revised the French of my Translation— He made no remark this time upon the language; but observed that an alteration was to be made in the English draft, to make it conformable to the French Note— It was accordingly made, and the Note was sent to Mr Harris to be copied— The Draft and Translation had both asked an Audience of leave for Mr Harris, as well as for Mr Bayard; Mr Gallatin remarked that according to the etiquette, no Audience could be granted to a Secretary of Legation; but that he must take leave, at an ordinary Circle— We therefore struck out that part of the Note— Mr Bayard then asked Mr Gallatin, whether he would mention the additional paragraph for the Note, which he had suggested to him as advisable last Evening.— “Not dissembling”—Mr Gallatin said, that he had thought we should state the ill impression which the Emperor’s neglect of sending the answer which we have been so long expecting, might make in the United States, and intimate the wish that if he meant to answer, and particularly if Great-Britain in refusing the Mediation had expressed any disposition for a direct Negotiation, that he would still dispatch the answer in time for them, (Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard) to receive it before they should leave Europe as otherwise the Emperor’s conduct might actually retard the restoration of Peace, which it had been the object of his offer to promote— But he said Mr Bayard had thought there might be an objection to such a paragraph— I said that I thought it would be best to avoid any direct written censure upon the Emperor; because however it might be expressed, the Count would feel himself bound in duty to defend his Master, and it might lead to a disagreeable and useless discussion— But in taking leave of the Count, Mr Bayard might verbally express any ideas of that kind which it might be useful to suggest— We had gone far enough in our reply to the Count’s Note, when without noticing at all his zealous apology for the Emperor we merely say, we had hoped, after so long a lapse of time, he the Count would have been able to give us a definitive answer— I believed the Emperor would feel the force of that remark, and I hoped he would feel it in a proper manner. They both said they thought the paragraph might be so worded as to give no Offence, but it was finally concluded to leave it to be given verbally, by Mr Bayard to Count Romanzoff.— Mr Gallatin asked me some questions relative to the charges I usually made in my Accounts for contingent expences of the legation, of which I informed him fully; and I told him I had now charged for the loss on Exchange, in consequence of his having told me that he had written to me, it was a loss for which the United States made allowance— After leaving these Gentlemen I called upon Mr Harris, to explain the erasure from the Note, relating
relating to him— I found him at dinner, and therefore stopp’d only to tell him the motive for the change— In the Evening he sent me the Note to be signed—

20. VII:15. By day-light, I took Charles this morning to school, and walked home— The cold continues intense— We sent for Charles again in the afternoon, as he was engaged to a party in the Evening at Mr Krehmer’s. I received from Count Romanzoff a letter with a Translation of the Emperor’s Rescript to the Minister of the Interior, directing him to issue a patent to Mr Fulton, for his Steam-Boats— Mrs Smith was quite unwell.

21. VI—15. Took Charles again to school this morning, and walked home— The thermometers on the quay being at -26. I found it excessive on crossing the river— This is the day of the new Moon, but it produced no change in the weather— After breakfast I went to Mr Meyer’s, and called at Mr Schubert’s, but he was not at home— A Mr Gold of Salem brought me a letter from Mr Hazard at Archangel.— Mr Harris came and shewed me a statement in the form of a letter to Mr Bayard, of his two last Conversations with Count Romanzoff, to whom he first went at Mr Bayard’s request to sollicit an answer to the former of our two recent Notes, and afterwards a second time at the Count’s own request.— Mr Bayard had desired Harris to draw up this statement in writing, and then to put it on record in the Official Book of the Mission— On reading it over, it immediately struck me, that it ought not to be recorded as an official document— First, because there was nothing official in the transaction; and secondly, because if so recorded it would be liable to be published in America; and many things were said by the Count in the Courts which he could not have intended or supposed would ever be published, but which might be the cause of giving him great trouble hereafter— I observed therefore, that if Mr Bayard thought proper, he might have a copy of this paper, either on a loose sheet, or entered into his separate Book; in which case, I should wish to have a copy of it also entered upon mine— As the letters of Mr Baring to Mr Gallatin had been— But not upon the official records of the Mission. Mr Harris remarked that besides the objections I had stated, by making the Paper an official document, it might appear an improper proceeding on his part towards Count Romanzoff, as it certainly would— He mentioned that in his Consular capacity, he had informed Count Romanzoff he should leave no Vice-Consul, as in the present state of affairs there was little or nothing to be done— But if there should be anything it would be attended to by Mr Norman.— He asked me to accept his Bust of General Washington by Houdon, and His Bust of the Emperor Alexander, together with a Copy of the Voyage of d’Entrecasteaux. He consulted me upon what he should do with the Archives of the French Consulate, which Mr Lesseps had deposited with him. As Mr Bayley the English Consul takes his house, it would be obviously improper to leave them there. In my house I have not room for them— He concluded to have them placed in an Apartment of Mr: Normon’s lodgings, and to leave the key with me.— I read this Evening some pages of Dr Rush’s last work, on the Diseases of the Mind— It is a melancholy subject, but he treats it in an amusing manner. There is nothing profound in his theory; and he appears rather prone to infer a general Cause from solitary particular effects; a source of much error in the Science of Medicine, and in many others— The Evening was clear, but dim, and we surveyed the skies without making any discoveries.

22. V. Within the 24 hours after the new Moon the Cold abated very considerably and a change of character in the weather is manifest.— The sky was of course overcast. After breakfast I called upon Mr Harris to see the state of my Book, containing the copies of letters and documents relating to the Extraordinary Mission— And I found several letters still to be copied into it— He said Mr Bayard had been satisfied that the Statement of his, Harris’s late Conversations with Count Romanzoff should be copied into his separate Book, and not upon the Book of Official Records— He also told me that Mr Bayard had received Notice that he would have an Audience of leave of the Empress Mother, the day after to-morrow.— I called again upon Mr Schubert, whom I found at home, and to whom I took the little Volume published at Boston by Judge Davis, upon Comets. I had much Conversation with him upon Astronomical Subjects, and he promised to lend me Bode’s Uranographia. I mentioned to him Adam Smith’s fragment on the History of Astronomy, of which he had never heard and which I promised to send him. I asked him about Kepler’s Manuscripts, which are in the Library of the Academy of Sciences, and of which he told me he had made great use in composing his Popular Astronomy. He did not recollect among Kepler’s Manuscripts
having seen the one against Calvin, but he had paid not much attention to the theological works. He would however look over them again and see if he could find the one about which I enquired— There were twenty-four Volumes of the Manuscripts, among which was a collection of Letters; but there were few of them that were interesting, so as to deserve publication— One of the letters is to his wife, in answer to a request from her that he would send her some money to buy fire-wood in the midst of a severe Winter— He writes that he has no money to send her, and can get none; but he advises her to apply to Tycho, and hopes he will lend them so much as she wants for fire-wood. Mr Schubert spoke of the Comet of 1811. which he said had been observed by one of the travelling Members of their Academy, long after it had been supposed that it would be no longer visible; and from those Observations it was ascertained that the Period of that Comet was more than 3000 years— From Mr Schubert’s I went and brought Charles home from school— The remainder of the day I employed in writing— Mr Smith dined and spent the Evening abroad.

23. IV:30. And wrote untill Breakfast time— The hours are always short when they are employed. I read prayers for the 3d: Sunday, after the Epiphany, and Massillon’s Sermon in the Petit-Carême, on the Temptations of the Great—Pleasure—Flattery—Ambition. These Discourses were preached to Louis 15. in his childhood, and this one particularly contains excellent doctrine and advice— They were not lost upon Louis, in his Youth; but the tempters were afterwards too strong for the teachers, and Louis became the slave and the victim of pleasure. I called upon Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and took with me the Note yesterday received from Count Romanzoff— I found Mr Harris there— Mr Bayard had this Morning had his Audiences to take leave of the Empress Mother, the Grand-Dukes Nicholas and Michael, and the Grand Duchess Ann. He was much gratified with the graciousness of the Empress— Mr Harris had also taken leave.— He told me that he had asked Mr Gallatin, about inserting in my separate Book, copies of his letters to Mr Baring, and that he had objected to it; saying they were private letters and had no relation to the Mission— They certainly were private letters, but their contents do principally relate to the objects of the mission, as Mr Gallatin sufficiently shewed by putting them into Mr Harris’s hands to be copied— Mr Harris being the Secretary to the Mission, and not the private Secretary of Mr Gallatin— However as he objects to my having copies of his letters, I shall not insist upon them— We agreed to write a dispatch to the Secretary of State, enclosing Copies of our last two Notes to Count Romanzoff and his answers. Mr Bayard asked me to draft the dispatch— I said that as it would relate altogether to his proceedings I thought he had better make the draft— He said he had not time, being engaged in his preparations for departure and if I declined doing it, he should be obliged to postpone it untill his arrival in England. I accordingly made the draft this Evening— A dispatch of three lines; barely referring to the enclosures— I asked Mr Gallatin for the copy which I had decyphered of the dispatch from the Secy: of State, of 23. June last.— He offered me laughing four of the undecyphered copies, if I would let him take that— But I did not relish the labour of decyphering it a second time, and advised him to let his son James take a copy from mine, to which he at last assented.— He asked me to lend him my Register of the Thermometer; wishing a copy from it, during the time that he has been here— I sent it to him in the Evening.

24. VII. Rose by daylight, though I was obliged to use Candles about an hour for reading and writing. I took Charles to school; and then called at Mr Norman’s lodgings to ask him to dine with us; but he was confined to his chamber by Indisposition.— Called at Mr Meyer’s, to ask him to negotiate another Bill upon Amsterdam to-morrow. Walked out about half an hour before dinner— Messrs: Gallatin and his Son, Bayard, Harris, Slade, Lewis, Bates and Hurd dined with us— Mr Tracy whom I had invited, sent an excuse, being engaged, but came and spent the Evening with us— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard intend going to-morrow.— Captain Bates goes also to-morrow, for Amsterdam. Mr Gallatin brought me back my Register of the Thermometer, but Mr Bayard had not received my draft of a letter to the Secretary of State, which I sent him last Evening. It was sealed and addressed to Mr Bayard, but I sent it under the cover to Mr Gallatin— He received it, and gave it to one of the Servants to take it to Mr Bayard, who was then not at home— How it was mislaid is not explained, but Mr Bayard did not receive it.— Mr Gallatin brought me three of the cyphered Copies of the dispatch from the Secretary of State of 23. June, and promised to send me my decyphered copy to-morrow morning. He asked Mr Harris for the three full-Powers to the Mission, and the Papers received previous to the 31st: of October, when he said he had withdrawn from the Mission— His Note having been written to Count Romanzoff, announcing this, on the 2d: of November— As the Powers had been originally entrusted to him, he thought himself answerable for the disposition of them; and the
disposition he intended to make of them was to give the Powers to treat with Great-Britain to Mr Bayard, and the Power to treat with Russia to me— Neither of them were now of any validity, as a new Commission must have issued to Mr Bayard and myself— But this was what he thought the most proper disposal of them.— I asked again what was to be done with Count Romanzoff’s Original Notes, but this was left undecided. I told Mr Bayard that if he went to England I thought he would stay there untill the Summer, and that Mr Gallatin would go home alone— He faintly opposed the idea, but in terms from which I conclude that such is his own expectation. Mr Gallatin told me that he had seen me and one of my brothers in February 1788 at Newbury-Port, lodging with Dr Kilham— Of this Circumstance I had not the most distant recollection— The first time I had ever seen Mr Gallatin as I supposed was at Washington, on my return from Europe in 1801— But I think one of my brothers did pay me a short visit at Newbury-Port in February 1788 during the Winter vacation at College, and Mr Gallatin must then have seen us— Mr Harris wrote me a short Note in the Evening to say that Mr Bayard had not found my draft of a letter, that I had sent him last Evening, and to ask for another which I accordingly sent him—I believe in the same words as the other.— I received this morning from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies a Notification for a Court to-morrow, being the reigning Empresses Birth-day— Charles came home from School, where it is a Holiday to-morrow on the same Account.

25. V:30. The reigning Empress, Elizabeth’s birth-day; on account of which, the Empress Mother, Marie held a Court, to which I went with Mr Smith at Noon— It was very thinly attended— The only other foreign Ministers there were Lord Walpole, and Count Maistre, with Mr Jouffroy, the Prussian Chargé d’Affairs— The Empress mother continues extatic, at the state of political affairs— The Emperor she said crossed the Rhine on the Anniversary of the day on which he had crossed the Niemen; and the allies are penetrating into France without meeting any thing like resistance. General Betancourt, and the Minister of the Interior Kosodavleff spoke to me about Mr Fulton’s Patent, which Mr Kosodavleff said he could not deliver untill there should be a specification, as the law required. But he promised to write me on the subject. I told him I should be perfectly satisfied that he should keep the Patent, untill Mr Fulton can send a Power to receive it and a specification— After the Court was over I called upon Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard, who were packing, and on the point of departure— I took leave of them— Went to Mr Schubert’s and left Smith’s philosophical Essays— He sent me Bode’s Celestial Charts which I took home— Looked over two or three of them untill dusk.— Mr Gallatin sent me a trunk of Papers, and Mr Bayard his Cards to take leave to be sent round.— Charles was disappointed this Evening of his party— Madame Bardaxi, the Spanish Minister’s Lady, died at 11. this Evening, of the Consequences of the dreadful accident she met with, the day before the Russian New-Year.

26. V:30. Took Charles to school this morning, and afterwards called upon Mr Montreal. He delivered me the papers he had procured for me, and after Breakfast came to explain Circumstances relating to them— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard went off last Evening about ten O’Clock. I have been several days much interrupted in my ordinary walks by the weather which has been little else than a continual fall of Snow. I was engaged the greatest part of this day in looking over Bode’s Celestial Charts— The Constellations which I had ascertained by La Lande’s Abridgment are sufficiently marked on these Plates; which will give me facilitie to find out some others— But the grouping of the Stars in most of the Antient Constellations appears extremely absurd, and the modern Northern Constellations consist almost entirely of stars scarcely perceptible to the naked eye.

27. VII. Mr Harris called upon me this morning and informed me that it was his intention to leave the City and follow Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard next Saturday week— He gave me a Copy of his Note to Count Romanzoff relating to his departure, and to his arrangements of the Consular affairs— He said he had delivered to Mr Gallatin at his request all the original Papers, respecting the Extraordinary Mission— Mr Gallatin has taken them all with him; or delivered them to Mr Bayard excepting the Power to treat with Russia, and four Copies of the Dispatch from the Secretary of State of 23. June 1813. Harris told me also that he believed it was Mr Gallatin’s expectation to be re-nominated at the present Session of Congress, for a new Commission, to treat directly in England.— I went and paid a visit, leaving a Card at Mr Bardaxi’s. I was employed great part of the day in looking over Bode’s Uranographia.

28. VI:30. On rising this morning I found the sky clear, but in the lapse of half an hour there was too much daylight to discern the stars— I had only time to ascertain the two Stars in the scales of Libra, which were so faint that I could barely perceive them. In addition to the Northern Constellations which I had already found out I traced though not with perfect certainty part of Perseus, the foot of Andromeda, and Capella descending to the Horizon, which I had only seen at Night, and near the Zenith— Looking as I do through double windows, and into an atmosphere always loaded with vapours, I find I can perceive with the naked eye no smaller stars than those of the 5th: magnitude—and then only when 25 or 30 degrees above the horizon. My only assistance is an Opera-Glass of Ramsden, which shews more distinctly the same stars which the eye can see but dimly.— I made out a list of the Stars of the first magnitude on Bode’s Charts— They are 17. two of which, one in the foot of the Centaur; and the other very near it in the Cross, are not mentioned either by Schubert or La Lande— And I added four others of the second magnitude, but which some Astronomers rank with those of the first— Schubert names 12 of the first, and seven of the second with pretensions to rank as of the first— La Lande says there are 15 of the first, but names only 14. and 3 of the Pretenders.— Bode includes Athair, Procyon, and Spica among the first, and leaves Alphard, Castor, Deneb and Denebola among the second. Five of these Stars never rise at St: Petersburg— Acharnar, Canopus, Fomahant, and the two in the Centaur and Cross— Four of them, Castor Capella, Deneb, and Waga never set— Antares rises only four degrees above the horizon so that I have not yet discovered him; and Sirius, so celebrated as the brightest Star of the Heavens, being only 13 degrees above the horizon scarcely seems a star of the first Class.— The day and Evening were Cloudy— Nothing to be seen— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us untill Midnight.

29. VI:30. Another morning like that of Yesterday. Quite clear when I rose, but the day was dawning, and extinguished in less than half an hour the light of all the Stars. I saw more plainly than yesterday the two principal Stars of Libra, and found that two others which I see from the North side of the house; were the twins, Castor and Pollux descending to the Horizon. They are so situated that one of them never sets while the other sinks beneath the Horison about an hour every day.— I resumed the reading of Biot’s Astronomie Physique, and read part of his Chapters on Refractions and Parallax; but they have too much Algebra for me to understand them— Inspected Bode’s Charts again. The first and second contain the two Hemispheres of Aries and Libra, with the Stars to the 6th: magnitude— The eighteen others are particular sections, on a larger scale, and contain the stars to the eighth magnitude. They mark the star on Flamsteed’s and Mayer’s Catalogues, which was the Planet Uranus, and the spot of its discovery by Herschell in 1781.— I dined with Mr Smith at Mr Raimbert’s— Besides his family there were Mr de Tracy, Mr de Castres and Mr Harris.— I asked them all to dine with us next Thursday. The day was clear and cold; the Evening moderate and clouded.

30. VI:45. The weather has so moderated that this day the Thermometer was at -only 3 and 4. The effects of this great change in the atmosphere are great on the body, and not small upon the mind. The sudden relaxation of the fibres produces a sort of dizziness in the head, which is painful and distressing.— Charles complained of it, and I felt it very sensibly almost the whole of this day.— The effect upon the Spirits is not less remarkable; but this does not extend to Charles— I read Prayers for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany, and Massillon’s Sermon upon the Respect to Religion due by the great—Respect of Fidelity, figured by Moses—Respect of Zeal, figured by Elias—as they appeared with Jesus at the Transfiguration. In the Evening I read a few pages of Dr Rush’s Book; and shewed Charles the whole Collection of Bode’s Charts.

31. V:20. Took Charles to school, intending to walk home; but I was instantaneously seized with the Rhumatism in the loins or Lumbago, which has so often afflicted me, since I have resided in this Country. I suffered with it severely the remainder of the day, and was obliged early in the Evening to take a foot-bath and retire to Bed. Mr Montreal was here this morning; and Mr Harris in the Evening.— Mr Harris had a letter from Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard, dated at Jamburg 40 Versts this side of Narva. It had taken them two days and Nights to get this far.

Day. The month has been so much occupied in writing letters, and with Charles’s lessons during his Vacation, that my reading of Astronomy and Mathematics has been almost totally suspended. I shall endeavour to resume these Studies if my time and health will permit.
